subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
The {{etyl|zhx-min-pro|-}} reconstructed form is ''*toiᴮ'' ({{zh-ref|Bodman, 1980}}). The relationship of this to the ''-n'' forms in other dialects is unclear and two theories exist:
* Old Chinese ''*tˤorʔ'' divergently developed into (1) ''*toj'' in southeastern China, and (2) ''*ton'' elsewhere ({{zh-ref|Baxter and Sagart, 2014}}). Compare also:
** {{och-l|端|tr=*tˤor}} vs {{och-l|瑞|tr=*[d]or-s}}
** {{och-l|算|tr=*[s]ˤorʔ-s}}
** {{och-l|卵|tr=*k.rˤorʔ}}.
* Proto-Min may represent the original Old Chinese form, and the forms in other Chinese varieties are due to confusion with {{och-l|斷|to cut}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

STEDT sets up two roots for this: {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*t(j)u(ŋ/n)||short}}, whence {{cog|my|တောင်း||short (as in garment)}}, and {{m|sit-pro|*dəw||short}}, whence {{cog|my|တို||short}}, {{cog|lus|tawi||short}}.

subSections.title: Pronunciation
subSections.text:
{{zh-pron
|m=duǎn
|dg=дуан2
|c=dyun2
|c-t=on2
|g=don3
|h=pfs=tón;gd=don3
|j=duan2
|md=dōi/duāng
|md_note=dōi - colloquial (“short (''of distance'')”); duāng - literary (“short; deficient; shortcoming”)
|mn=xm,zz,tp,kh,tn,yl,mg,hc,tc,ph:té/qz,lk,sx,km,hc:tér/toán
|mn_note=té/tér - colloquial; toán - literary
|mn-t=do2
|w=2toe
|x=donn3
|ma=y
|mc=y
|oc=y
|cat=a
}}
